content: @indigoxela Thanks for starting to port Riddler! I'm a fan of that CAPTCHA, looking forward to using it on my sites. :)

@Jack @indigoxela I was musing over whether we should combine some anti-spam modules and/or put some in core. It's seems like I usually have to install more than one on all my sites. No hurry on this but could make things easier for people by providing a standard
Speaking of Riddler

https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/3624 and https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/1169 would be the place to discuss that :wink:

[SR] Dedicated "Security" section under "Configuration" · Issue #3624 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
I would like us to have a dedicated "Security" admin page and a respective Admin menu item in order to: show that we take security seriously allow site admins to perform security-related ...
[SR] Include Honeypot module in Backdrop by default for public forms. · Issue #1169 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
The comment module is included in core. That's fine BUT... Normal users aren't savvy enough to know that by enabling forms, they're exposing their sites to spammers and the likes. And, ...
Oh, indeed, Riddler is my favorite if Honeypot isn't enough. Great to hear that it's available for Backdrop!

Cool, I'm not the only one considering Captcha Riddler a very effective antispam module. :wink:

I had to do some rewrite to make use of config_get_translated(). Is anyone willing to test it? Or is someone from core team willing to review?
I can test it next week - no code review, though.

@Herb I like these ideas! Especially the idea of putting some in core, since they feel so essential. I do worry -- how do we pick which ones to include? And how do we make sure we're not being too heavy-handed in loading stuff into core?
Oh oops posted that response before seeing the other updates here! Thanks @klonos for sharing that Honeypot in Backdrop core post that I knew I'd seen somewhere
@indigoxela I'd also be up for testing Captcha Riddler sometime soon!

Regarding putting functionality in core: the hard part would be choosing the modules. Different sites need different solutions. Some are well-protected with Honeypot alone, some even need combinations of antispam modules, some don't need any additional protection from contrib.

How to figure out what the "80%" are?

Usage stats of modules compared to the total amount of Backdrop sites help make decisions... https://backdropcms.org/project/usage/backdrop shows roughly 1250 sites, and https://backdropcms.org/project/usage/honeypot shows 170 ...that's a ~14%
...next, there's the fact that we cannot ship core with a solution that relies on a 3rd party service (like CAPTCHA/reCAPTCHA, Akismet, Molom etc.), as there are privacy/licensing concerns, and also the matter of what happens when these services have outages and/or go out of business.
...another factor is code complexity.
So when it comes to honeypot, it is a simple, self-contained solution ...it may not be as effective for all sites as some of these 3rd party services are, but it is better than no protection at all.
I still prefer Antibot over Honeypot...
I'm pretty undecided now. If there's some baseline minimum that we think won't change much, and is independent of third parties, it'll make sense to include in core

the thing that turns me off about antibot is it forces the end user to have javascript enabled (https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/javascript-trap.en.html) I'm not as strict about it as Stallman, but it is a pattern we've never used in Backdrop before all our nojs fallbacks provide a working interface for the user; antibot just says you can't use this form unless you bend to our will

I wonder if it makes sense to have some core anti-spam API that each module could use and leave the rest for contrib. It would make it easier to add something to a form to protect it. For instance, honeypot and captcha both have to discover forms and have a way for users to decide if a particular form needs protection
Right now each module does it completely differently

I've used for years very simple approach without javascript needed - just CSS: https://github.com/findlabnet/anti_bot - contact and comments form should be detected and added on install automatically.

findlabnet/anti_bot
Anti bot module for Backdrop CMS. Contribute to findlabnet/anti_bot development by creating an account on GitHub.

Herb said:

Right now each module does it completely differently

Different modules provide different (form) protection approaches, if one doesn't work in situations, another one still might do. :wink:
Most of them are working with the form api - so that's probably the common denominator.

Personally, I'm comfortable to have form spam prevention in contrib. Ask three people, what the best approach is and you get five answers.
@Vladimir Oh, that's also an interesting approach... Checkboxes as bot traps... Why didn't you release it in backdrop-contrib?

@indigoxela I didn't want to start one more disqus for "How many modules with same functionality we need" - it was a time I have such issue in another module. On the second side - possible names collision.

the thing that turns me off about antibot is it forces the end user to have javascript enabled

@Geoff St. Pierre (serundeputy) I wonder what the percentage of users with no JS/JS turned off are... Is it worth the time & effort to provide non-JS fallbacks for what I'm assuming is a less than 20% (likely even less than 5%) population?

When it comes to spam protection, diversity rules! What works best depends so much on what you need to prevent (silly bots, smarter bots, click workers, (human) forum spammers...).

Again - I doubt we could ever find consensus on the approaches that should go into core. This discussion here already seems to proof it. :wink:

@indigoxela Regarding Riddler: When I try the 'Manual installation' in the Backdrop interface, I get: The info file (...)riddler.info does not define a 'type' attribute. For now, I can install it otherwise but the 'type' attribute is needed anyway.
^^ Installed Riddler now via SFTP, didn't test it thoroughly but works as expected for me. ^^
we're going to need to add something else on b.org too, we have honeypot, antibot, and akismet and are still getting spam
Ooops, right, the type was missing in info file. Fixed now. @Olaf Grabienski many thanks for finding out, I totally missed that.
